title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Learning objectives

Understand and apply programming principles to handle repetitive tasks
Understand how to use and make your own functions in R
Use loops in R
Apply these principles to perform efficient data manipulation, analysis, and reporting

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Goals
At a bare minimum, we want our code to be:


Organized

Coherent structure of

folders, files, and scripts


Transportable

Works on

my future computer
other people’s computers



Understandable

Clearly specified dependencies
Readable code, sensible naming of things
Written documentation explaining what and how

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Extras
Nice to have, but not absolutely necessary
Provably correct
Through automated testing

Pieces of code correctly do what they should
Code works together correctly, not sensitive to minor changes in the data
Valid statistical properties

Version controlled

History of development is tracked and documented

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
How to achieve these goals?
Building an R package is one way, with many distinct advantages
Documented structure and community-based conventions

Large community who know how to use packages
Smaller community who know the standards
Infrastructure to make the process easier and better

Building R extensions

195 pages of standards and instructions
Changes with every R release (every year in the Spring)

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Infrastructure

devtools
usethis
roxygen2
testthat
pkgdown
Countless blog posts, books, workshops, etc.

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
What is an R package?

“A directory of files that extend R”
A package can be installed, which means

the directory is copied to your library which is your local directory of packages

It can be built, cleaned, documented, and source code compiled
It can be checked, tested for consistency and portability


Woody: Buzz, you’re flying!
Buzz Lightyear: This isn’t flying, this is R coding with style.

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Description
The DESCRIPTION file contains basic information about the package in the following format:
Package: pkgname
Version: 0.5-1
Date: 2015-01-01
Title: My First Collection of Functions
Authors@R: c(person("Joe", "Developer", role = c("aut", "cre"),
                     email = "Joe.Developer@some.domain.net"),
              person("Pat", "Developer", role = "aut"),
              person("A.", "User", role = "ctb",
                     email = "A.User@whereever.net"))
Author: Joe Developer [aut, cre],
  Pat Developer [aut],
  A. User [ctb]
Maintainer: Joe Developer <Joe.Developer@some.domain.net>
Depends: R (>= 3.1.0), nlme
Suggests: MASS
Description: A (one paragraph) description of what
  the package does and why it may be useful.
License: GPL (>= 2)
URL: https://www.r-project.org, http://www.another.url
BugReports: https://pkgname.bugtracker.url

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
License
Pick a license, any license
Failing to include a license implicity declares a copyright without explaining if or how others can use your code
I prefer the MIT license, it is short and understandable to lay people
https://opensource.org/licenses/alphabetical

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
R code
The R/ subdirectory contains your code

One or more .R source files
Defines objects that are part of your package, usually functions

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Namespace
A text file that specifies the directives of your package

Imports: which objects to include from other packages in yours
Exports: which objects to make available to users of your package

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Documentation

The man/ subdirectory contains documentation files in a specific format
The vignettes/ subdirectory contains long form documentation in pdf or html format

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Everything else
Files

README, NEWS
configure, cleanup, INDEX

Subdirectories

tests, data, inst, src
exec, po, tools, demo

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Lessons

60 minutes
Work through a problem together, discuss issues and strategies

Sticky note system

 = “I need help!”
 = “Good to go!”
No sticky = still working

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Lectures

30 minutes
Highlighting concepts, resources, tools

volunteers needed!

title: Programming and statistical modelling in R
text:
Programming and statistical modelling in R



The aim of the course is to make the participants able to

use programming principles (loops and functions) to handle repetitive tasks
use functions in R
use loops in R
do efficient data manipulation and aggregation




The course covers use of the statistical software package R. The aim is to take the intermediate R user to the next level, and make use of programming techniques for more efficient use of R. A key focus in on introducing loops and functions. The course will consist of lectures and exercises over 4 days. This will give the students a chance to use and work with different aspects of R.



Ph.D.-students and health researchers with a basic knowledge of statistics corresponding to the course on basic statistics for health researchers and with a good working knowledge of R, e.g., as obtained by having already followed an introductory course on R.
Participants are expected to bring their own laptop with R installed for the exercises.



The course is relevant to PhD students from the following graduate programmes at the Graduate School of Health and Medical Sciences, UCPH:
ALL GRADUATE PROGRAMMES



English.



Lectures in four half days, four optional exercise hours placed as one each week.



Michael Sachs, Section of Biostatistics



Michael Sachs and other members of the staff at the Section of Biostatistics.



1, 4, 8, 11 November 2022, all days from 8.00-12.00.



CSS

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Why?

If your research involves any data analysis, it likely also involves:

Data management and manipulation
Analysis
Reporting of results

This means lots of code.
We can borrow some ideas from software development to

Make our lives easier – repetitive tasks, updates with new data
Make science better – reproducible, understandable, reusable

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Overview of this course
Lessons

45 minutes
Work through a problem together, learn tools and strategies

Sticky note system
 = “I need help!”
 = “Good to go!”
No sticky = still working

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Exercises

Work on your own
Answers shared after the course

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
What I do

Develop and evaluate statistical methods

Write R packages
Write R code to test the methods

Collaborate on research projects involving data analysis

Use register and other data from stats Denmark
Data analysis, visualization and reporting

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
My R philosophy

I started learning R in 2005 (version 2.2)
There is almost no problem that can’t be solved with R

Flexible and dynamic
Plays nicely with almost any other programming language

title: Introduction and Overview
text:
Course philosophy

There are no stupid questions
There are many ways to solve a problem, there is no single “right way”
I will not force you to learn any particular way, e.g., tidyverse vs data.table, we will focus on learning the general principles.

Try them out, then choose one and get good at it
Same with project organization, choose a system and stick with it

Show up to class and participate, you will pass and hopefully learn something useful

title: Introduction and Overview
text:

Today

Data structures and indexing

Friday

Flow control and loops
Creating and using functions


Tuesday

Working with data, merging and reshaping
Working with data, dates and characters

Next Friday

Reporting, dynamic documents
Case study, analysis of register data

title: Project organization and workflow
section: R session and the working directory
text:
R session and the working directory

getwd()

[1] "/home/sachsmc/Teaching/Courses/r-programming/lectures"

list.dirs(".", recursive = FALSE)

[1] "./projects_files"

list.dirs("..", recursive = FALSE)

[1] "../_site"           "../.git"            "../.quarto"        
[4] "../.Rproj.user"     "../example-project" "../exercises"      
[7] "../lectures"       



The R session runs in the current working directory
Input and output happens relative to that directory
"." means “this directory”
".." means “the directory that this one is contained in”

-- README.md

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
Set up projects
Quick review of the file system

File system discipline: put all the files related to a single project in a designated folder.

This applies to data, code, figures, notes, etc.
Depending on project complexity, you might enforce further organization into subfolders.

Tools to facilitate this

ProjectTemplate package
Several other packages: https://cran.r-project.org/web/views/ReproducibleResearch.html#project-workflows
Make your own template structure and copy-paste

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
Navigating the directory from R
Compose directories and files with file.path (it is safe and works in any OS)

read.csv(file.path("..", "rawdata", "lisa-2012-full.csv"))
write.csv(analysis_file, file.path("..", "data", "analysis-data.rds"))

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
Get comfortable
Your workflow does not matter, as long as you follow the principles.
Options for IDEs (all free):

Rstudio
VScode
emacs

All of these support projects, have integrated help files, code completion, and syntax highlighting.

Why?
See the UCPH Policy for Research Data Management

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
The here package

library(here)

read.csv(here("rawdata", "lisa-2012-full.csv"))
write.csv(analysis_file, here("data", "analysis-data.rds"))

The first line figures out the root of your project directory: is there an .Rproj or .here file there?
Then, here allows you to build paths to subdirectories, starting from the project root.
Use this in your scripts, and everything will run nicely, both interactively and programmatically, no matter what your working directory is (as long as it is in the project).

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
What?
Personal taste and habits (“workflow”) versus the logic and output that is the essence of your project (“product”)

The editor you use to write your R code.
The naming/specific structure of your project directory.
The R code you ran before lunch.

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
Setting the working directory

Open the .Rproj file in a fresh R/Rstudio session
Open an .R file in a new session
Use the drop down menu in Rstudio: Session > Set working directory
Use setwd() in the terminal

Avoid using setwd() in scripts

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
Practical

Create a toy project using your favorite tools
Swap projects with your neighbor
See if you can reproduce each others results

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
The importance of README

Always include a README.txt or .md file at the root of the project
Plan, Document, Share, and Preserve
To include: what and how:

Title of the project
When it was last updated
What is included in the project directory
How to run the analysis and use the results (including what dependencies are needed)
A license describing the conditions of use

title: Project organization and workflow
text:
Bad vs good habits
Do not:

use setwd() in scripts
rely on rm(list = ls())
save .RData when you quit R and don’t load .RData when you launch R.

Do:

Restart your R session frequently while working
Set the working directory on launch or interactively
Use relative paths, or here if your project directory is complex

title: Project organization and workflow – exercises
text:
Create your project directory
In this lesson we will organize a toy project about the Palmer Penguins dataset. In the end you will share the project with your neighbor and ask them to reproduce your results, so keep that in mind.

Create a new folder on your computer for this project. Name it whatever you want but something short but informative.
Using a directory structure of your choice, set it up as a project template. Remember to include a README file. This project will involve some data input, manipulation, and some output of figures.
Acquire the Palmer Penguins dataset from here

title: Project organization and workflow – exercises
text:
Do some data manipulation

Create a new .R script in the appropriate directory of your project.
Open up the R script in your IDE
Read in the penguins dataset and create a new variable called the “penguin body mass index”. It is the body mass in grams divided by the square of flipper length in millimeters
Save the results in your project directory, try using the here function.

title: Project organization and workflow – exercises
text:
Do some data analysis

Create another .R script
Make a scatterplot of body mass index versus bill length, with color by species
Make a boxplot of body mass index by sex.
Do a t-test for body mass index by sex.
Save the results in your project directory, try using the here function.


Stop and think
You are going to share this project with your friend. In order for them to reproduce the results that you obtained, they will need the same data. Think about different ways that they can obtain the dataset. What are the pros and cons?

title: Project organization and workflow – exercises
text:
Share with your neighbor

Update your README file.
Zip up the project folder and send it to your partner.
When you recieve their project, unzip it, open it in a new R session and try to reproduce their results.
